PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Administrative Services. Given the evidence before the State Bank Royal Commission in South Australia that the Bannon Government donated $2m of taxpayers' funds to the bank to keep home loan interest rates down for the duration of the 1989 State election campaign on condition that the donation was not publicly disclosed through the bank's books, and given the Federal Government's supposed determination to stop political corruption through legislation to introduce disclosure of political donations, will the Minister agree that money deals, such as the Bannon Government's secret donation to its State Bank to procure votes, should be investigated in the context of the Political Advertising and Political Disclosures Bill 1991 and prohibited by legislation? Or does he believe that secret money deals by governments to influence election results are acceptable, while secret money deals by individuals and organisations are not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: — What is quite striking about the question from the failed former Opposition leader in South Australia is that it comes from that side of Parliament-from those who historically have been experts in pork barrelling. I can see that the National Party is quite embarrassed at the way in which Senator Olsen has asked this question. Senator Olsen raises matters that are clearly before the Royal Commission in South Australia and obviously they are matters for that Commission.
—Go back to your telephone box; you are better there.

—Here he rises from the bottom of the harbour. This is a melting pot society and in all melting pots the scum rises now and again, and there it is. The matters are before the Royal Commission; they should stay there and should be assessed there.

ANSWER.PARA: In terms of whether these matters are in any way related to the Bill before the Parliament, this Bill does not seek to confuse the matters Senator Olsen raises with the basic principle that honourable senators should understand, which is that disclosure legislation should relate to and provide clearly and openly for full disclosure of donations to political organisations, whether they are political parties registered under the Act or third party organisations registered under the Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —That deal is all right.

—Senator Kemp says that that deal is all right. Allegations have been made, and he in his normal conservative way in this place comes in and asserts that those allegations are true. I will not accept that. I leave those allegations to be determined by the Royal Commission. I also say that we are concerned here to ensure that our disclosure legislation is as comprehensive as is possible under the Australian Constitution, so far as we can go federally, to ensure that donations to political forces in this country are disclosable to the public.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister to comment on the principle as to whether this is the type of deal he wants outlawed in future? Does the Minister want to ensure in legislation that governments are treated in the same way as individuals, third parties and organisations within the community, or does he want to have two sets of rules-one for incumbent governments and one for others within the community?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I could understand then, and I can understand even more now, why Senator Olsen did not, despite his good judgment in terms of football teams, win government in South Australia. The basic thing about government activities-no-one should know it more than us at the moment-is that when governments make decisions they are open to parliamentary scrutiny. We are going through the exhaustive process right now of Senate Estimates committees, where every item of government expenditure is subject to scrutiny. In those circumstances if, in the hypothetical case that Senator Olsen raises, there is a particular problem, it can easily be disclosed and, in fact, can be dragged out.

ANSWER.PARA: He is talking about the normal machinery of government. He is talking about normal government decision making. He is talking about the allocation of funds. Senator Olsen can understand quite clearly that, when we are talking about that, all those activities are subject to the scrutiny of the forums of both the Senate and the Estimates committees. Of course, if there were any problem it would come out. No matter what degree of obfuscating Senator Olsen might get into, the basic point is that at the end of this process he and his party, and the National Party which, in recent days, has emerging problems with this, will have to confront the basic issue: will they or will they not support full and adequate disclosure of donations to political organisations? I am sure that what they have been about from the start is to hide their secret backers. That will emerge as this process continues.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs whether he saw Mr Hadyn Park of the National Australia Bank on the 7.30 Report last night defending the current rates of interest on credit cards made available by the major banks in Australia? If so, I ask whether he believes that credit card holders should get a reduction in interest rates in line with the fall in official interest rates.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt that with the nine reductions in interest rates that have occurred since January 1990 there should be some flow-on of those reductions to the persons who hold credit cards in our community. Because we are a credit ridden society, most people-I have no doubt most honourable senators-hold a credit card of some sort from their bank or other financial institution. The fact is that over those 20 months or so when there have been nine reductions in official interest rates only a few banks reduced their interest rates by about one per cent last July. I think the Commonwealth Bank reduced its rate from 24.6 per cent to 23 per cent. There is still a huge gap between the official interest rates that are now available and the interest rates that are charged by the banks for the use of credit cards by their customers. That gap should be narrowed for the benefit of credit card holders. I believe that with the nine reductions in official interest rates over the last 20 months credit card holders deserve a much better deal from their banks.

ANSWER.PARA: It is true that some credit card holders have the temerity to pay off their bankcard, or whatever it might be, within 30 days and therefore they do not pay the interest rates. That has to be acknowledged. But the fact is that, whilst the banks make much of that fact, it is also true that the shopkeeper, the retailer, the restaurateur and the hotelier all pay a fee to the bank for the privilege of being able to offer the goods or services and having them paid for on that credit card arrangement. In fact, the banks do get a payment from all those providers of the goods and services when a credit card is accepted.

I saw yesterday in the Sydney Morning Herald the first admission ever from Westpac's Assistant Chief Manager of Retail Banking, Mr Don Easter, that the bank's credit card operations had broken even over the past four or five years. The line from the Australian Bankers Association has been that this has been an unprofitable area of activity. I believe that consumers out in the marketplace who hold credit cards ought to get the benefit of the reduction in interest rates. There should be some reflection from that particular reduction in interest rates seen in their credit card rates. I hope that consumers use their power out in the marketplace to switch to those financial institutions which offer a lower rate of interest on their credit arrangements.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Did the Prime Minister promise during the last election campaign that the Medicare levy would not be increased? Do the Prime Minister and the Government intend to keep that promise?
—The answer to that question is yes. The Prime Minister said so yesterday. I do not know why Senator Herron wants me to repeat it.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What is Australia's present position in respect of the carrying out of United Nations resolutions 194, 242 and 338?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —United Nations General Assembly resolution 194 was adopted back on 11 December 1948. It was one of the early attempts to resolve the Arab-Israeli and Palestinian issues. Among other things, it established the United Nations Conciliation Commission to assume the functions of the UN mediator on Palestine-Count Bernadotte-who was murdered in Jerusalem on 17 September of that year. It resolved that Jerusalem should be placed under a permanent international regime under United Nations control. It also resolved that refugees wishing to return to their homes after the 1948 Arab-Israeli war and live in peace with their neighbours should be allowed to do so and that compensation should be paid for the property of those choosing not to return and for loss of or damage to property. Australia voted in favour of that resolution. Among states which voted against were, regrettably, Egypt, Iraq, Lebanon, Saudi Arabia, Syria and Yemen.

ANSWER.PARA: Since that resolution was adopted almost 43 years ago, there have been dramatic further developments in the region, including three major wars between Israel and its neighbours. Australia's current attitude to that resolution is that the broad issues it canvasses should be discussed in the context of a peace conference between all the parties involved.

UN Security Council resolutions 242 and 338 were adopted after the 1967 and 1973 Arab-Israeli wars respectively. They call for Israel's withdrawal from territories occupied during the 1967 war and respect for and acknowledgment of the sovereignty of every state in the region and their right to live in peace within secure and recognised boundaries.

As Australia was not a member of the Security Council in 1967, we were not entitled to vote on resolution 242. We were on the Security Council in 1973 and we did vote in favour of resolution 338. As I have made clear on several occasions, including through a news release as recently as last month, on 3 August, Australia has for many years supported a comprehensive solution to the Middle East dispute based on these Security Council resolutions and the principle of land for peace.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Social Security to a meeting held with welfare groups in Adelaide in October last year in which he committed his Department to several measures, including the provision in every Department of Social Security office of information regarding the legal rights of DSS clients. I also refer the Minister to his response to my question of 21 June this year regarding the whereabouts of these leaflets when he undertook to make the leaflets available in CES offices also. Firstly, what steps has the Minister taken to ensure that the leaflets are available in CES offices? Secondly, why have field officers and mobile review teams not been handing out the leaflets to DSS clients as promised by the Minister? Finally, why have the leaflets on legal and appeal rights been printed but still not made publicly available in all social security and CES offices as promised by him in October last year and again in June this year?

—After the last question Senator Lees asked on this matter I, naturally enough, consulted the Department to find out why the leaflets did not have the wide distribution I had promised. There had simply been an error and many of those pamphlets had been left sitting in an office. As a result of that discovery, my understanding is that they were very quickly pushed out, not only to the offices of my Department but also to CES offices and certainly to mobile review teams. In fact, from the inquiries I made originally I am quite certain that at least some mobile review teams were handing them out. I will have to check further to see whether the information I received probably about two months ago was correct.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Information received by my office as late as Friday of last week indicates that no offices-either CES or DSS-in South Australia have these leaflets available. It seems from information I have received this week that they are also not available in New South Wales. Can the Minister please give us some date when these leaflets will be available?

—All I can say is that, according to the information I had before, the honourable senator is not correct about their not being available in any offices in South Australia and New South Wales. I will have to check whether or not that is true and, if the honourable senator is right, I will give her a date when they will be available.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is the Minister aware of an advertising campaign being conducted by the Victorian Trades Hall Council into alleged media bias against trade unions in Victoria? If so, is the Secretary of the Victorian Trades Hall Council correct in his assertion that the number of working days lost through industrial disputation in Victoria is half the level in New South Wales and is falling far below industrial disputation figures of 10 years ago? Does the Minister agree with the reports of statements from Mr Des Moore of the Institute of Public Affairs that Department of Industrial Relations figures show the real picture that nearly half of all disputes were in Victoria during May?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the campaign publicly announced by the Victorian Trades Hall Council against what it calls media bias. I make no judgment as to whether or not it is appropriate to conduct such a campaign and, therefore, I make no judgment as to whether the grounds exist for one. However, I make the observation about media bias that, in my experience, resort to the Australian Press Council or the Australian Journalists Association Ethics Committee concentrates the minds of editors wonderfully. Nothing brings them up quicker than to have to print a retraction in their newspapers after an adverse finding by either of those bodies.

ANSWER.PARA: I have been asked a question in two parts by Senator Childs concerning the level of strike activity and the comments made recently by Des Moore of the Institute of Public Affairs. The answers to those two parts, in sequential order, are yes and no. To the first part of the question about what are the strike statistics in Victoria, the Victorian Trades Hall Council is dead accurate when it asserts that disputes in Victoria are half the level of those in New South Wales. The Australian Bureau of Statistics figures for May show that the number of working days lost per 1,000 employees in the year to May 1991 was 147 in Victoria. This was 52 per cent below the rate of industrial disputation in New South Wales, which had 306 working days lost per 1,000 employees; and 37 per cent below the Australian average of 202 working days lost per 1,000 employees.

Since the Hawke Labor Government came to power the rate of industrial disputation in Victoria has dropped by 72 per cent compared with that of the Fraser years. Held against a national average of a fall of 62 per cent, it can be clearly said that the rate of disputation in Victoria has fallen further than in other States. I have made statements about this, and I note, too, that those statements have not been reported. There seems to be an obsession with ignoring the facts and going to the spectacular in terms of reporting incidents of disputes rather than getting any sense of proportion.

I now turn to Mr Moore. Mr Moore says that the real picture is shown in the publication on disputes produced by my Department. My Department's figures mainly show the number of disputes rather than address the index of working days lost per thousand. Therefore, the figures comment on incidents; they are rapidly accumulated. They are figures which my Department does not pretend to be the final word at all. We respect the ABS as the independent statistician in this case. Its figures come later, they are collected over time and are a more reliable index.

The figures my Department collects hope to show changes and our immediate response to what is happening in the environment. To pretend that the ABS figures are not to be regarded as authoritative, in view of the survey results that my Department produces, is of course entirely inaccurate.

I conclude by saying that one of the most outstanding features during the Hawke Labor Government's period of office, in terms of industrial disputes, is that the cause of disputes, as registered by the statistician, has changed. The cause of disputes in this country is no longer substantially over wages and working conditions. The cause of disputes is, as the statistician describes it, over managerial policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Defence-maybe these figures do not appear in Senator Cook's statistics either-to the six-week long nationwide work ban by Public Sector Union personnel working in military outposts in response to the Government's plan to rationalise and decentralise stores holding and handling accounts in the Department of Defence. I also refer to the fact that the PSU objections are based on the requirement for union members to be managed by military personnel. Has the Minister seen reports that the union is now prepared to agree to the devolution of power of civilian management at outposts but that the question of military management should be deferred? Will the Minister inform the Senate whether he will agree to this proposal or is he committed to the Government's rationalisation and decentralisation reforms? If so, what action will he take over the work bans?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As in most initial industrial disputes, Ministers do not take a direct involvement but require the various people to get together. The main industrial dispute is, of course, at Zetland in Sydney. We have had bans applied by the Public Sector Union because of the defence regional support review. The dispute is basically about the various recommendations concerning the devolution of civilian personnel administration delegations.

ANSWER.PARA: There was an agreement reached with the PSU in settlement of this current dispute. However, the most recent meeting in September failed to conclude that agreement. That was of some surprise to me. I thought that the basic grounds for agreement were there.

Following a further meeting between management and the PSU on 4 September, in which the Naval Support Commander agreed to defer implementation of the restructuring procedures until December, the PSU was going to recommend to its members that all bans be lifted. I think that the PSU is meeting with its members tomorrow to that end.
The dispute, in the principal area, is still not resolved. We have not indicated that we would revoke our previous position. The position now is that a final decision will be made in December.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I asked the Minister whether he is committed to his rationalisation and decentralisation reforms and what action he was going to take over work bans. Is he prepared to allow this to drag on until December? He said that it was primarily at Zetland. It is, however, in fact causing work bans right around the country. Is he prepared to allow the union to dictate the tune on defence reforms?

—That question, of course, is put in such a way as to already prejudge any answer that I will give. Of course I am committed to those reforms, of course I am not going to allow the unions to dominate absolutely this discussion, nor am I going to exclude the union from the discussion. It is representing people who have worked in the defence area for a long while. It is entitled to put a point of view. It is entitled to negotiate. I am entitled to consider its position. Whether, in the long run, I agree with its position will be a matter for those sorts of discussions to continue. On the basic principle, yes, I am committed to those sorts of reforms. I believe that, with proper consultation and proper discussion, the work force will come to agree with that position.

—I address my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and refer to comments in the press in recent days that suggest that the reforms to the depreciation system announced in the March industry statement have become bogged down in discussions between business and government officials. Can the Minister clarify the situation on these important matters?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that the depreciation changes announced in the March statement were to be subject to discussion between officials of the Australian Taxation Office and business. There have been a number of disagreements over the interpretation of the depreciation reform announced in the March statement. The Treasurer said yesterday during Question Time that discussions with the business community are still under way on implementing the depreciation changes announced in that statement. The sticking point is the question of the definition of effective life for plant and equipment, and that has been a point of dissension during the discussions to date.

ANSWER.PARA: I agree with the Treasurer that the outcome of these discussions will lead to a more sensible depreciation system. That was the objective of the changes announced in March. I said at the time of the March statement that the changes announced by the then Treasurer would have a far-reaching impact on firms and lead to a more competitive taxation environment for investment. In particular, I said at that time that the definition of effective life should help ensure that asset lives afforded for tax purposes accurately reflect the actual period an asset can be expected to contribute to the income earning process.

I understand that business groups have argued strongly with Treasury and the Tax Office that the legislation should accurately reflect these words. I therefore welcome the Treasurer's comments yesterday that the Government would need to be more accommodating in further discussions with business.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Social Security to statements of his former ministerial colleague Stewart West that the failure of the Budget to deal with the unemployment facing hundreds of thousands of Australians was `a triumph of the ideologues and a slaughter of the innocents'. How many more innocents will have to suffer as the Minister and his colleagues allow the ALP leadership struggle to paralyse the Government?

—I am not as aware as Senator Knowles of Mr West's comments. I have not seen them, so I would not wish to comment on them. In terms of her more general point about the number of innocents, et cetera, the Minister for Finance in one report I read this morning suggested that 100,000 new jobs would be created in the second half of this financial year as the economy recovered. If that is the case, one would imagine that there would be many innocents gaining a job in the very near future.

—Can the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade give details on the progress being made on whether China, Taiwan and Hong Kong will participate in APEC? Can the Minister also indicate whether countries such as Mexico, Chile and other Latin American countries will be able to participate in APEC in the near future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to advise Senator Schacht and the Senate that it is now our understanding that the way is clear for China, Hong Kong and Taiwan to participate in APEC. The APEC senior officials meeting, which took place in the Republic of Korea just a few days ago, from 27 to 29 August, decided to recommend to Ministers that the People's Republic of China, Hong Kong and Taiwan be invited to participate at the November ministerial level meeting of APEC. That followed a long course of discussion and negotiation about the basis on which that should take place to the satisfaction of all parties concerned.

ANSWER.PARA: This, of course, fulfils one of Australia's major objectives for the development of APEC. Their participation will very much strengthen the organisation, and they too will benefit from the process of consultation on regional economic cooperation.

The terms under which they will participate were decided upon during a process of consultation conducted by Korea as the current chair of APEC. We understand that Taiwan will participate under the name Chinese Taipei as it does in the International Olympic Committee and the Asian Development Bank. We welcome the flexibility which has been shown by all parties which has enabled them to reach agreement. In particular, we congratulate Korea on its conduct of the negotiations.

In terms of the possible further expansion of APEC to extend to Mexico or other countries on the Latin American rim, no doubt that will be the subject of further discussion and consideration, but I would not imagine that any such additions to the membership should be regarded as imminent.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia and Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. I refer to the Federal Government's hypocritical and patronising rejection of a new mainland land council in south-east Arnhem Land to which Senator Collins has previously given specific obligations and support. Can the Minister explain why the wishes of the Aboriginal people were ignored and certainly not reconciled; why their 67 per cent Yes vote in last year's Government initiated plebiscite was dismissed by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs as not representing a majority; why the mainland Aborigines are treated differently compared with the Aborigines of Groote Eylandt; and whether the Australian Electoral Commission, which conducted the plebiscite, has been undermined as a result of this decision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again on these issues Senator Tambling is up a tree. The facts are that there was not a 67 per cent vote in the communities that were excluded from the boundaries. The reason why the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs came to the sensible decision that he did in respect of-I am pleased to say-establishing this new land council, which I have consistently supported personally for a decade, is because of Aboriginal representations. Senator Tambling should be aware of that.

ANSWER.PARA: The figure that Senator Tambling quoted was an aggregate figure for the outcome of the entire plebiscite which, of course, includes the majority of the population in the area-that of Groote Eylandt, where there was a very strong vote indeed in favour of the land council.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was the same on the mainland and at Groote Eylandt, and you know it.

—Regrettably for Senator Tambling's assertions, that is not the case. The difficulty was-and Senator Tambling, personally, has to take a considerable amount of the blame for this-that the progression of this land council became so hopelessly politicised by Country-Liberal Party politicians in the Northern Territory, that there was an extremely strong reaction from the Aboriginal leadership of Groote Eylandt expressed not just to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs but also to me about the inclusion of Ngukurr.

ANSWER.PARA: Unfortunately, the public relations campaign for the separate land council at Ngukurr was hijacked from the Aboriginal community by the person acting as its consultant, who is now the Country-Liberal Party candidate for the House of Representatives seat in the Northern Territory, Arthur Palmer. That is a matter of fact. I might add that he got himself a very substantial little consultancy out of the whole deal, too, and feathered his nest at the same time.

Representations were first made to me as the local member for Arnhem Land for a separate land council for Groote Eylandt in 1977. I have been directly involved in representations to the Federal Government since 1977 to establish that land council. Unfortunately, the divisions between the Groote Eylandt Aboriginal people and the people at Ngukurr became so intense and personal that there was legitimate concern that those divisions were going to cause very serious conflict between the two communities.

In those circumstances, the Minister responded positively to direct representations from the Groote Eylandt community that at this point in time Ngukurr not be included in the land council. Frankly, with that advice given to him by the Groote Eylandt leadership, the Minister was not in a position to do anything other than take the decision that he took.

It does Senator Tambling no credit to run this pathetic partisan CLP campaign on this issue which is of deep concern to the Aboriginal community in that area. There is nothing to prevent the boundaries of that new land council being amended to include those areas at a future time when negotiations between the Aboriginal people at Ngukurr and the Aboriginal people at Groote Eylandt are successfully completed-as I am sure they will be-without the involvement of any politicians. There is no reason why at a future time those areas cannot be included in a new land council. In conclusion, I commend the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, firstly, for establishing the land council and, secondly, for responding as positively as he did to the representations from Aboriginal people in the area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Once again the Minister has shown that he is deliberately playing favourites between particular communities-in this instance the Groote Eylandt community. I ask the Minister to clarify his statement that the mainland communities of Numbulwar and Ngukurr did not record a 67 per cent pro vote in a plebiscite on boundaries determined by the Government, for which the turnout was greater than for Federal, State or ATSIC elections. Why does the Government now determine to play favourites in this particular area for its own political advantage and not take into account the wish of the Aboriginal people in those communities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hate to confuse this political nonsense with a little fact, but I will do so. I would be interested to know how Senator Tambling can assert that there was a 67 per cent vote at the community of Ngukurr when the votes from Ngukurr were not counted individually but pooled with other ballot boxes in the area. It would be a very interesting trick. Maybe Senator Tambling had somebody looking over the shoulders of the voters at the plebiscite there.

ANSWER.PARA: I reiterate that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, firstly, is to be commended for establishing the land council after a 10-year struggle to get one and, secondly, for acting as sensitively as he did in responding to direct representations from Aboriginal people and ignoring the Country-Liberal Party and establishing the council on the boundaries that he did.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. The Minister will recall that on Tuesday I asked a question about Australian visa stamps placed on the passports of Taiwanese tourists and the consequence that this could have on the opening of direct air links between Taiwan and Australia. Could the Minister advise whether there have been any developments in relation to those air links since he answered my question on Tuesday.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be able to tell the Senate that last night in Taipei the technical annex to the airline services understanding between Australian and Taiwanese commercial interests was signed, thus enabling airlines from both sides to now lodge applications for operating approvals, the last stage of the process of establishing air links. Those remaining technical procedures could take a few weeks and I will make a formal announcement when a precise date for the commencement of services is known.

ANSWER.PARA: As I told the Senate on 3 September, two days ago, the Taiwan side did not insist that a visa disclaimer be dropped as a condition for the commencement of direct air services. The review of the disclaimer, which I also indicated that I had embarked upon when I spoke in the Senate two days ago, is a matter entirely separate from the air links issue and I shall make my decision, as always, on the merits of that case and in my own time.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Given the weight of accounting and tax evidence in Australia and overseas against the cash basis for swaps and the clear threat that the cash basis poses for the Australian financial system, why is the Australian Taxation Office insisting on this approach to the taxation of swaps?
—That is a question that I will have to ask the Treasurer to direct to the Australian Taxation Office.
—You wouldn't have a clue.

—The answer is that I would not have a clue because the Taxation Office is an independent authority, as Senator Alston might learn one day. The answer is that, of course, I would not have a clue. While the Tax Office is responsible to the Treasurer, it is in its day to day negotiations and dealings an independent authority. I will get the Treasurer to direct Senator Watson's question to the Taxation Office and obtain an answer for him as soon as possible.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister aware that in 1990 the Australian Taxation Office issued a draft ruling on interest in which it recommended that financial institutions tax account for interest on a daily accruals basis? Given that interest swap payments are effectively substitutes for interest payments or are analogous to interest payments, how does the Australian Taxation Office explain the inconsistency between its view on swaps in 1991 and its view on interest payments in 1990?

—The answer to the first part of the question is that because I have a great respect for Senator Watson's integrity, I am now aware of the facts which he has put to me. As to why the Taxation Office changed its view, I provide the same answer as I did to the original question: I will find out for him and will provide him with an answer as soon as possible.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is the Minister aware of recent reports from Amnesty International of an accelerating pattern of short term detentions, torture and ill-treatment of suspected political opponents of the Indonesian Government in East Timor, including at least 30 apparent extra-judicial executions by Indonesian security forces? What steps have been taken by Australia to attempt to improve the human rights of the East Timorese? Will Australia support Portugal's requests to the United Nations for a parliamentary delegation to visit East Timor?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am, of course, aware of the Amnesty report which contains the allegations referred to by Senator Bourne. The important thing to appreciate about that report is that it covers the whole of the three years since 1988. It was submitted to the UN in August and forms part of Amnesty's regular submissions to the UN on human rights in East Timor.

ANSWER.PARA: I certainly agree that there have been significant human rights problems in East Timor over the past three years and in particular, as I have acknowledged before in the Senate, in the period of September, October and November last year when the Indonesian authorities were responding to what they perceived to be an increase in security problems. Our embassy's assessment, based on a visit to the province again in June this year, is that the human rights situation is now significantly better. I do not think it is fair to characterise the overall situation as one of accelerating human rights abuse, as Senator Bourne suggested.

The Australian Government has attempted to improve the human rights situation of the East Timorese by, first of all, making it clear on many occasions to the Indonesian Government that we support the universal observance of fundamental human rights in all countries. We have done that very clearly and very consistently, both at the bilateral level and in multilateral forums, such as the UN Commission on Human Rights. Secondly, by making representations to the Indonesian authorities whenever we have received credible, specific reports of human rights abuse, I and my ambassador in Jakarta have regularly registered concerns at those reports with Indonesian Ministers.

The remaining point that was raised by Senator Bourne was about the parliamentary delegation from Portugal. Let me say simply that the Australian Government supports the idea of a visit to East Timor by a Portuguese parliamentary delegation and we do hope that such a visit will help Portugal and Indonesia overcome their remaining differences over East Timor.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. I seek advice from the Minister as to what is considered appropriate conduct for Federal Court judges. Where a Federal Court judge hears a matter in which one of the parties is a corporation of which he is the chairman, would the Minister expect that judge to disqualify himself from the hearing of the matter further and would a serious conflict of interest exist if the judge were to continue with the matter and make a finding in favour of the corporation of which he is the chairman?

—I regard it as unfortunate that Senator O'Chee should raise this matter in such a general way because I think it could be taken as an attack on any number of members of that bench of the Federal Court, under parliamentary privilege and without any real evidence. I am not asking that in a supplementary question evidence be offered of the particular case. I believe Senator O'Chee ought to make available to me in specific form any misgivings or concerns he has and I will ensure that the Attorney-General gives consideration to such evidence as he might bring forward.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am asking for an indication of the Government's attitude on what is the accepted and expected conduct of Federal Court judges. I hope the Minister will be able to answer that question now.

—I believe that judges on the Federal Court Bench have a good understanding of their responsibilities in relation to the hearing of cases, as is generally the case with those on the benches of all superior courts. As I said, I will not answer a question in such general terms, but if Senator O'Chee has anything specific he wants to put before the Attorney-General, which I then would take to be transmittable to the Chief Judge of the Federal Court, I will facilitate the transmission of such misgivings or evidence.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is it a fact that Robe River Mining is seeking to prohibit union membership among certain members of its staff under section 118 of the Industrial Relations Act? Is this, in effect, a case of the company seeking compulsory non-unionism? Can the Minister advise what the Government's attitude is to this use of section 118 by Robe River? Can the Minister also advise how many individual legal actions the company has initiated against the unions which represent its employees since 1986, when it began its industrial campaign? Can he advise what the financial cost has been to unions and their members by the company's apparent policy of constantly tying unions up in legal actions or threats of legal action?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answers to the questions are yes, yes, and it is an inappropriate use of section 118. If I can now turn to the other questions, I have to say that Robe River is the self-proclaimed leader of the New Right in Australia. It is certainly militant and it has set about systematically trying to deny the rights of its employees by the use of dismissals and stand-downs. It has a record of defying orders made by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. It is indeed a vexatious litigant, appealing even the most unremarkable decisions of the Industrial Relations Commission-one imagines in order to act out the New Right theory that one should excessively resort to the law.
—Mr President, on a point of order: I wonder whether you would ask the Minister to tell the Senate whether he is speaking as a Minister of the Crown or as a paid-up trade union official?
—There is no point of order.

—The most recent issues concern actions regarding the Australian Seamen's Union and Cape Lambert Services, which is a wholly owned subsidiary of Robe River and supplies the tugs for the towing of the bulk carriers to the wharf. Since 1989, in cases involving the Seamen's Union there have been some eight appeals by Robe River to the Industrial Relations Commission's Full Bench and two appeals to the High Court. The actions have all been about whether or not the same conditions that apply at all other ports in Australia should apply at this particular port, Cape Lambert.

ANSWER.PARA: In essence, the outcome of these appeals has been for the Seamen's Union to be upheld in all cases. Now that the appeals system has been exhausted and Robe has had nowhere to go, on Friday, 28 August, Cape Lambert Services went into voluntary liquidation. A new company, Westug, was formed immediately to take over the role of Cape Lambert Services. It now appears the case that the Seamen's Union is going to be proceeded against by the new company in the same way as it was by Cape Lambert. The outcome of all the appeals and the wins they have recorded are set at naught and so the process begins from scratch.

The conditions are that the Seamen's Union wishes simply that the same conditions that apply in all other ports in Australia apply here. I think that it is reasonable in the circumstances to observe, and I do so, that this is a contrivance, and a false contrivance, when at the end of an appeal outcome in which a company is then expected to abide by a decision, it goes into voluntary liquidation and another company is contrived to take its place and the process commences again. It is not unreasonable either to speculate that should the same processes be replicated with this company, as one would expect they would be, when the outcome is arrived at again and the final appeal source is exhausted, the existing company will go into voluntary liquidation and a new company will start.

In all those circumstances one has to say that this is behaviour within the law, but the law is an ass if it permits behaviour of this sort. These are the actions of an employer version of the BLF. In the circumstances I understand that the Seamen's Union is contemplating a nationwide strike. I earnestly counsel the Seamen's Union not to proceed to do that. It is not in the national interest, nor is it in the union's interest, irrespective of how one can feel that it has been provoked in these circumstances. But it means that some examination of this type of behaviour has to be undertaken so that it can be ended.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industrial Relations to the meat inspectors strike at Wodonga Meats on Friday, 30 August.
—Ah!

—The honourable senator can say `Ah' as much as he likes. This was a strike that was in direct defiance of award conditions which stipulate when rostered days off will be taken. First, will the inspectors who defied the award provision be disciplined? Secondly, will the Government, in its capacity as the employer, take action available to it under the Industrial Relations Act against the Public Sector Union for breach of award?
—Mr President--
—Try to be consistent on this one in view of your previous answer.
—Order, Senator Kemp!

—The Government is consistent in all these affairs. If there are breaches of the award, there are remedies available to the offended against parties, and those remedies can be resorted to, and should be, if there is any concern in the minds of those parties. In industrial disputation it is often far more sensible to consider what is the issue in dispute and come to terms that will settle that particular issue than immediately, and without consideration of what the justification of the initial grievance might be, resort to the heavy handed actions of penalties. Nonetheless, penalties exist and if there is behaviour by an organisation which offends against the law, then that action should be taken.

— I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister advise what action will be taken, as the Government is the employer, to reimburse abattoirs and meat workers that suffered commercial damage or wage losses due to the strike, given that the Meat Inspection Service is legislatively compulsory and something for which the abattoirs pay full cost recovery of $67,000 per inspector per year?

—In these circumstances, I believe that there is no obligation on the Commonwealth to reimburse anyone in this particular case. I will have a look at the matter but, as I have said, on my understanding of this issue I do not think there is any obligation. It is not appropriate in a case like this that there be any compensation paid.

—I ask the Minister for Social Security whether his attention has been drawn to claims made through the media by Adrian Nizzola, former manager of the Permanent Building Society in Western Australia, that the Department of Social Security had early warning of the freezing of the Society's funds. Did the Department of Social Security try to stop payments to the Society on Thursday before it became public knowledge that the Society's funds had been frozen? What arrangements have now been made for pensioners and beneficiaries to access their last fortnight's payment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I answered a question on this yesterday morning. Later in the day, despite a denial, Mr Nizzola, the former managing director of the Society, in some radio interviews made the specific allegation that an attempt had been made to stop payments on Thursday. I can repeat only what I said in the Senate before, that the Department did not have knowledge and that no attempt was made to stop payments on Thursday. In fact, had the Department had knowledge on Thursday, one wonders why a Reserve Bank cheque should have gone to Westpac for the Society for the payment of JSA and Newstart benefits on Friday. We had been unable to stop that because we did not find out about it until after the close of business on Friday when there were media reports in Perth about the fate of the Society's funds. Obviously, it is normal for the Department to try to get cheques into any building society of this kind on a working day prior to when our beneficiaries would begin to withdraw money. In fact, we were successful only in stopping payments that would otherwise have been able to be claimed on the Tuesday.

ANSWER.PARA: Having said that, in answer to the final part of Senator Beahan's question, my Department has had discussions with the administrator and my office has had discussions with the Attorney-General in Western Australia. I can now announce that the administrator has agreed that social security payments credited to the Permanent Building Society during the week ended 30 August can be withdrawn in full. That can be done after the production of a letter from the Department, which is going out today to every pensioner and beneficiary so affected.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the other old people with money in there?

—That will mean that the last payment received can be accessed in full by all the beneficiaries. If beneficiaries are concerned about the balance of their accounts, in accordance with the administrator's normal rules, they will have to satisfy the hardship provisions. But the administrator has accepted, in answer to Senator Panizza's interjection, that pensioners and beneficiaries-not being the wealthy people in our society but people who do draw out the great bulk of their payments every week-would be in great hardship were they not able to access their last payment. That is why the administrator has agreed with exactly what was said.

—I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to the appalling situation in Yugoslavia and, in particular, to reports overnight that the Yugoslav armed forces have effectively cut Croatia in half. I remind the Minister of the statement over a week ago by the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, that he had discussed with President Bush the option of United Nations involvement to try to bring to an end this tragedy. Now that it appears that the European efforts are failing, what has the Government done to pursue the option discussed by the Prime Minister and Mr Bush?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although I agree with Senator Hill that the situation in Yugoslavia at the moment is very distressing in the sense that the cease-fires manifestly have not held and heavy fighting continues, it is nonetheless premature to say that the European peace process has come to a conclusion. A few days ago, on 2 September, the European Community, along with the Yugoslav Federal Government and the six republican governments, signed a cease-fire agreement calling for a halt to the use of force and the separation of the warring forces. Compliance with the cease-fire agreement is not the subject at the moment of any monitoring arrangement, but it is proposed to be observed by an international monitoring group.

ANSWER.PARA: According to the EC plan, the next steps are the holding of a peace conference in The Hague with all the parties, starting on 7 September-this weekend-and chaired by Lord Carrington, together with the establishment of an arbitration commission to examine the differences of the parties in Yugoslavia. The EC plan rejects any changes to borders brought about by force. There are unspecified threatened additional measures, no doubt involving, among other things, economic sanctions, should one of the parties not agree to these conditions.

Our position has been to warmly endorse this exercise by the EC and the Yugoslav parties concerned and to urge all parties to respect the terms of the cease-fire agreement and to get around a table and try to resolve the issue. I think it is still possible for the issue to be resolved in this way. The option of United Nations involvement, which was canvassed by the Prime Minister with President Bush, is still a rather difficult option to implement and operationalise to the extent that we are still talking about an internal situation within traditional Yugoslav borders not yet spilling out elsewhere. Although there have been recent precedents of a kind in international affairs in the context of the Gulf, the Kurds, and so on, which suggests an evolving disposition on the part of the UN to be willing in extreme circumstances, through the Security Council and other organs, to look at these issues, it is universally acknowledged that at the moment this is a very difficult issue on which to get agreement.

So although it remains an option which we will of course take further in the event that the European peace process breaks down, we and the United States both want to give priority to the European peace efforts. We certainly would not be minded to try to pre-empt those efforts while they still have any life in them. I repeat that it is premature to make the judgment that they do not have any life in them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I put it to the Minister in the form of a supplementary question that it is very difficult to maintain that the European proposals have not broken down when the cease-fire has obviously been flagrantly abused by the Yugoslav armed forces. Acknowledging that the Minister has said that the UN proposal is a difficult one, would it not have been useful to use this time available to pursue that option and to look at ways of overcoming the obvious difficulties because the alternative may be too late?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand what Senator Hill is saying. Obviously, what our policy response should be is under continuing and very close review. I repeat that for the moment we do want to see how the European process works. It is a very hands-on one involving not only the European Community but indeed the whole CSCE apparatus, with the EC operating as the delegate of the CSCE. It is manifestly an apparatus without any of the constitutional or charter constraints that afflict the UN. On the face of it, it does seem likely to be a more productive route for reaching a resolution of this, given the constraints that exist with the UN.

ANSWER.PARA: Obviously the UN option is very much alive, but I think it is premature to try to take it any further at this stage. However, I repeat that we will obviously be keeping the situation under close review.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 16 August Senator Watson asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question about tax simplification. I recall the question because he made the charitable suggestion that the departure of Treasurer Keating was a loss to the country. I concur with that view. The departure from the front bench of any Minister in this Government is a loss. The answer the Treasurer has provided is somewhat complicated, so I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

The income tax simplification project was a joint review by officers from the Australian Taxation Office and the Treasury. The work of the review team was completed (not abandoned) in August 1990 with a submission to Government.

After due consideration of the submission, the Treasurer through a Press Release issued on 13 December 1990, announced the first tranche of simplification measures including self-assessment and foreign source employment income and indicated that into the future, simplification proposals for change would be implemented incrementally.

Rather than an abandonment of simplification, the Government has therefore foreshadowed its ongoing evolution. Subsequent measures have included a review of depreciation as announced in the March Industry Statement, 1991.

Moreover, it should be noted that issues of simplification are intrinsic to the manner in which legislative and administrative proposals are formulated within the Australian Taxation Office which seeks to bring forward proposals which minimise costs of administration and of compliance to the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Crichton-Browne asked me a question as to whether a Mr Ken Colbung had been `thrown out' of the office of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has advised me that the answer to the honourable senator's question is no.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the Minister's answer.

This will take just a couple of minutes. Information was given to me by a very senior Aboriginal who came directly to my office from the Minister's office. He is a longstanding Chairman of the Institute--
Government senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I ask you to ask Senator Faulkner to withdraw that remark.
—Senator Faulkner, I ask you to withdraw the comment you made.
—Mr President, I cannot withdraw any comment because all I did was laugh. I made no comment.
—Order! I did not hear the interjection. I thought it was Senator Faulkner, but obviously it was not.

—The facts have been given directly to me by Mr Colbung. He has an impeccable reputation in terms of the job that he does and the role that he has played in the Aboriginal community not only in Western Australia but Australia-wide. In particular, the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies, of which Mr Colbung is Chairman, and its Principal are having a great deal of difficulty making any contact with the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner). They had asked the Minister to open their day for Aboriginal Week at the Institute. My understanding is that he had accepted but then declined. He was asked to visit the Institute some time during the day, but he could not manage that. Mr Colbung asked whether he could see the Minister, and the Minister could not even do that.

SPEECH.PARA: So Mr Colbung presented himself at Parliament House. This caused some consternation in the Minister's office. The Minister then agreed to see him. He spoke to Mr Colbung for 10 minutes and then in the midst of the conversation, in a very unpleasant and angry way, he got up, slammed his book shut and said, `If you're not leaving I am'. He then walked out. Mr Tickner's staff then told Mr Colbung in a very unsavoury way that he had to get out, too. He left and came to my office. What Mr Colbung does not know is that the staff in my office were contacted by the Minister's staff and told that, if Mr Colbung caused any trouble for me in my office, they would come and rescue me because they were responsible for him as they had signed him in.
Government senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—I note that it is very amusing for the Government. Government senators can have a lot of laughs; but there is more to come. I did not see them, but I understand from my staff that some time later two of Mr Tickner's staff arrived at my office door to inform my staff that Mr Colbung was unable to move around the building because he had a pass which required that he be accompanied and that they had come to get him. I did not tell Mr Colbung about that either, because I thought it was a bit humiliating. Senator Schacht must think that is very funny.
—You have never had any interest at all in Aboriginal affairs.

—That shows the ignorance in which Senator Schacht basks. Mr Colbung came to my office because of my reputation in Western Australia for care and interest in Aboriginal affairs. I assume he also came because I am a past member of the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies.
—This was going to be a couple of minutes-to quote you, senator.

—I did not expect the response that we have received from the Government. Ultimately, when my office was able to assure Mr Tickner's office that I was quite safe and that Mr Colbung could be moved around the building without the able assistance of Mr Tickner's staff, Mr Colbung was accompanied by one of my staff to Mr Chaney's office.

SPEECH.PARA: If I were to speculate, I would have to say that the Minister realised how disgracefully both Mr Colbung and his wife had been treated. When Mrs Colbung dared to make a comment during the conversation, one of the staff said, `What would you know about Aboriginal affairs? You are not even Aboriginal'. I suspect that the Minister's office was highly embarrassed. On sober reflection, they thought that if they could extricate themselves and get Mr Colbung out of my office before he told me the sad sorry story, they would relieve themselves of some embarrassment.

I put it to Senator Collins, with respect, that if he is suggesting that Mr Colbung was not thrown out of Mr Tickner's office, he is misleading the Senate and has been misled by Mr Tickner. If Senator Collins would care to ring Mr Colbung personally, I am sure that he would reinforce everything I have thus far told the Senate and that which he told the ABC this morning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief, but a response is required. I am sorry to hear, I must say, so soon after commending the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner) in Question Time, that any offer to rescue Senator Crichton-Browne was made by the Minister's office. I will take that matter up with his office.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason I am responding to this is that I have known Mr Ken Colbung personally for a very long time. I not only respect him but also like him; I have a lot of time for him. I am sorry to hear that he was involved in any kind of difficulty in Parliament House. I can assure you, Mr President, that on a personal level I will contact Ken Colbung, whom I know well.

I reiterate that I put to the Minister's office yesterday Senator Crichton-Browne's question, which was that Ken Colbung was thrown out of the Minister's office. The advice I received from the Minister was that that was not correct.

I want to make some specific points about the matter that was raised yesterday. The documents tabled yesterday were provided to the Senate in accordance with the normal practice; that is, as soon as the necessary clearances were obtained. As most honourable senators would know, there are guidelines for presentation of ministerial statements and reports to Parliament. Those guidelines in relation to the House of Representatives state that reports and papers will normally be presented in the House on the sitting day following receipt of the report by the tabling officer, although programming considerations, especially where a statement accompanies tabling, may create delays. This week all of the documents presented to the Parliament have been tabled one sitting day or less after becoming available.

The guidelines also state, with regard to the Senate, that in most cases reports presented to the Senate will have already been presented to the House, usually on the previous day. Exceptions to this general rule are where the report is the responsibility of a Senate Minister, where there is a particular requirement for simultaneous tabling or--

TALK.START.PARA: —Why not simultaneously?

—There has been a longstanding practice and that is the point that I am explaining. That was the point of Senator Patterson's proper concern yesterday. Let us get this point on the record and we can subsequently talk about this sequencing arrangement which, as I understand it from honourable senators who have been here longer than I, was originally introduced to facilitate the Opposition-not this Opposition now-but that does not mean that it has to be set in concrete.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to get the facts from yesterday correct first. The report is usually tabled first in the House in which the Minister sits and subsequently in the other House. When it is a Senate Minister-as was the case with two of the reports yesterday-the reports are tabled first in the Senate and subsequently in the House of Representatives. That also happened with regard to the documents that were tabled yesterday. When it is a House of Representatives Minister, the documents are tabled first in that House and subsequently in here. That is why that circumstance-the matter which Senator Patterson raised-occurred yesterday. It was news to her and to me, but it has in fact been the practice for a very long time. There was no departure yesterday from the standard practice with regard to that matter. Had there been, Senator Patterson is right: that would have been a profound cause of concern. But it was in accordance with that standard practice.

I reiterate that we endeavoured yesterday to proceed in as cooperative a manner as possible. We had negotiated with the Opposition about the manner of presentation of those matters. I will come to Senator Bishop's point in a moment. What I have said does not go to more general questions of concern about whether reports should be tabled in both Houses simultaneously.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope you don't use that precedent for the Budget Papers.
—That is not really one of Senator Watson's more profound interjections. There was no special arrangement yesterday, the potential of which had alarmed some honourable senators, including me.
—Does that mean that these have been tabled in the House of Representatives?

—No, they have all been tabled simultaneously today, for reasons which I will come to in a moment. Had they been tabled in the House of Representatives, they would have been available in advance, because they would then have been tabled in accordance with normal practice. That is why we always have a large number of reports on the list, most of which are available in advance and some of which are not, either because they are being tabled for the first time by Senate Ministers or they are being simultaneously tabled for some particular and specific reason. That was the case yesterday, on every other day, and it is the case today.
—To cover the two-hour rule.

—I will come to Senator Bishop's point in a moment. I ask her to restrain her enthusiasm just for a moment. If honourable senators want to discuss whether the guidelines should be changed, I am quite happy to listen to those discussions. It does not strike me as one of the world's greatest issues, but there is no barrier to having some discussions about it if people have a particular view.

SPEECH.PARA: The change may not be totally in the interests of the Senate; the sequencing often makes it easier for people to debate documents. Most reports, because of this procedure, are tabled in the House of Representatives one day and tabled here the next day. That gives us more time to discuss them later that day because they have been received from the House of Representatives. The procedure usually works in our interest, but I am not averse to having discussions about changing it. There is no particular government interest in whether they are all tabled simultaneously or otherwise. That is not a matter of any consequence.

With regard to these particular reports-and some of those yesterday about which Senator Baume spoke more broadly as to whether they should have been in earlier from the departments-irrespective of which House they were tabled in on which day, I do not intend to stand up here and defend every agency and their timetable of presentation. Some come late for good reasons; some come late for no reason at all. I have no quibble with the right of senators to express concern about that. Whether they are right on every occasion is a matter of judgment, but they are entitled to raise that as a proper concern, because departments do have a responsibility to report. I do not challenge that point.

We have set out to be cooperative, including in the tabling of the various documents today relating to Estimates committees. It may be that they should have been tabled two weeks ago. I do not know when they could conceivably have been available; they are not reports with which I am familiar. That is why we made an exceptional arrangement today to facilitate both Opposition and Government senators in the consideration of these reports at Estimates.

I cannot debate whether they should have been available a fortnight ago; I have no information about that. But we have set out, in the knowledge that the Estimates Committee is scheduling Prime Minister and Cabinet for Monday, to make these reports available in a slightly unusual manner so that honourable senators have them prior to Estimates Committee consideration.

The speech read as follows-

This Bill was presented to the House of Representatives on 18 April this year as a Private Members Bill by Mr Ron Edwards, the member for Stirling, and the Bill passed through all stages in the House on 21 June.

Whilst Mr Edwards' motivation in introducing the Bill was to overcome an impasse in the introduction of summer time in Western Australia, the Bill has a broader impact by clarifying the Commonwealth's responsibility for civil time in Australia and its external territories. Because time is such an important component of the National Measurement System the Bill has been adopted by the Government and it is on this basis that I introduce the Bill to the Senate.

The current legislative responsibility for civil time is divided between the National Measurement Act 1960 and Time Acts of the State Governments. These latter Acts were enacted in 1894 as a result of an International Meridian Conference in 1884 that recommended the establishment of a global system of time zones based on the Greenwich Meridian of longitude with zones based on one hour difference for each 15 degrees of longitude. It is under these pre-Federation State Time Acts that some State Governments have set their summer time.

With Federation in 1901 the Commonwealth was given responsibility under Section 51 (xv) to establish a National Measurement System. In accordance with this responsibility the Commonwealth in 1947 acceded to the Convention of the Metre and in 1959 to the International Convention on Legal Metrology. In 1948 the Commonwealth enacted legislation, now the National Measurement Act 1960, defining the legal units of measurement in Australia including the measurement of time.

However no provision has yet been made in the Commonwealth legislation for defining civil time. In 1975 the Fifteenth General Conference of Weights and Measures recommended that Co-ordinated Universal Time based on atomic clocks replace the solar based Greenwich Mean Time as the basis for legal and civil time. Australia is now one of the few, if not the only, modern industrial nation to have not enacted national legislation defining civil time.

The passage of this Bill will clarify the Commonwealth Government's responsibility for civil time and will remove any legal anomalies in the definition of civil time with respect to Co-ordinated Universal Time.

The Time Zones defined in the Schedule to the Bill have been defined with respect to Co-ordinated Universal Time but are consistent with the zones defined in the existing State Time Acts. In addition time zones have been defined for Australia's external territories, consistent with their geographic position.
The Bill also makes provision for setting of summer time by regulation following consultation with the Premier or Chief Ministers of the States or Territories.

Summer time was first introduced in Australia in peace time by the Tasmanian Government during a severe drought in 1967. The aim was to save water in the hydro-electric systems and the success of the experiment has resulted in its continuance in Tasmania and adoption of summer time by all the States and Territories except Western Australia and the Northern Territory.

Whilst summer time has a high degree of acceptance in Australia, a Morgan Gallop Poll in March this year indicated some 74 per cent of the population in support, there has been great difficulty in obtaining uniformity of summer time with the result that the three standard time zones can be expanded in summer to up to seven zones creating major difficulties for transport and communication utilities.

Summer time has been adopted in all industrialised countries except Japan and most middle income countries. However each summer in Australia it still generates a high degree of passionate public debate. There is in Australia a deal of current debate about the moves by European community to establish a single market in goods and service; what is less well recognised is the extent to which continental Europe has established uniform standard and summer time. This Bill will provide the opportunity to introduce a summer time regime that is appropriate for our climate, geography and economic welfare and in addition will allow for a review of the existing time zones to ensure that they meet current business and community needs.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

HONEY LEVY (NO 1) AMENDMENT BILL 1991

This Bill provides for amendment to increase the maximum allowable Honey Levy on honey produced and sold in Australia. The Bill is one of three similar Bills, each dealing with a different way of selling honey, which provide for an increase in the maximum allowable levies or export charge on honey to 0.75 cent per kilogram. The levies and export charge are imposed to provide the basis for funding the Honeybee Research and Development Council.

Under the present legislation the maximum allowable levy for research and development is 0.50 cent per kilogram, which is the same as the current operative rate. The operative rate is determined by Regulation on advice of the Federal Council of Australian Apiarists' Associations, which is the national representative beekeeper organisation, or the Honeybee Research and Development Council.

The Federal Council of Australian Apiarists' Associations has advised that it wishes to increase the operative rate to 0.52 cent per kilogram from 1 January 1992 as part of its program of progressively increasing the producer contribution to research and development.

To allow for this increase and any further increases, the Federal Council of Australian Apiarists' Associations has requested the raising of the maximum rate to 0.75 cent per kilogram. Increasing the maximum rate by 50 per cent will give industry the flexibility to increase its contributions to research and development over an extended period without the need for frequent amendments to the legislation.

The Government commends the industry's foresight and support of the need for increased research and development. The Australian honey industry is currently contributing about 0.4 per cent of its gross value of production to research and development.

Research and development is a major factor underlying this country's future growth. The Government is committed to continued matching of industry levies for funding of research and development up to 0.5 per cent of gross value of production. This has continued to encourage rural industries to increase their contributions to research and clearly the honey industry recognises the advantage of this commitment in moving towards the 0.5 per cent target.

No additional budgetary outlays will result from the amendment itself. However, this amendment would enable the Government to agree to an industry request for an operative rate increase above the current maximum, which would then generate additional matching budgetary outlays.
I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators and I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.
HONEY LEVY (NO 2) AMENDMENT BILL 1991

This Bill provides for amendment to increase the maximum allowable Honey Levy on honey produced in Australia and used in the production of other goods. The Bill provides for an increase in the maximum allowable levy to 0.75 cent per kilogram. The levy is imposed to provide the basis for funding the Honeybee Research and Development Council.
I have already outlined the background to this amendment in my Second Reading Speech on the Honey Levy (No 1) Amendment Bill 1991.

No additional budgetary outlays will result from the amendment itself. However, this amendment would enable the Government to agree to an industry request for an operative rate increase above the current maximum, which would then generate additional matching budgetary outlays.
I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators and I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.
HONEY EXPORT CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1991

This Bill provides for amendment to increase the maximum allowable Honey Export Charge on honey exported, but not levied under other legislation.
