SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The passage of the Social Security (Disability and Sickness Support) Amendment Bill 1991 is about as tedious as the negotiations on this legislation have been since it passed through the House of Representatives. I remind honourable senators that this Bill went through the House of Representatives with no amendments. It came into the Senate and went to a committee, and now today we have on the table 111 amendments and five or six requests. We have seen a Bill which was passed through the House of Representatives in a shoddy and disgraceful form, mainly because of lack of consultation and which now, because of consideration of Estimates in the Senate, which is no excuse, the Bill is taking quite a while to get through the Senate as well.

SPEECH.PARA: It is irrefutable that over the past 20 years there has been a massive rise in the number of invalid pensioners and sickness beneficiaries, far exceeding any increase in the Australian population. Let me reiterate a few of the figures which I find rather startling, as I am sure will some members of the public, especially the few of us who are left who are taxpayers. The number of invalid pensioners has risen from 134,000 in 1970 to 229,000 in 1980, to 316,000 in 1990. This is an increase of 136 per cent in just 20 years, and in that time the population has risen by only 36 per cent. In 1990 one in every 56 Australians was on the invalid pension compared with one in 93 two decades earlier. If we take carer's pension and other related benefits into account, we find that over 422,000, or one in 40 Australians, were receiving long term disability assistance in June 1990-one in 40 Australians!

The number of sickness beneficiaries has risen from 10,000 in 1971 to 39,000 in 1980 and to 70,000 in 1990. This is a massive 654 per cent increase in 19 years. In that time the population has risen by only 31 per cent. In 1990 one in every 230 Australians was receiving sickness benefit compared with one in every 1,240 in 1971. This means that one in 34 Australians was receiving some sort of short or long term disability related assistance from the Department of Social Security in 1990-I repeat, one in 34. As two-thirds of our population are at working age, this equates to one in 22 of working age Australians in receipt of some form of benefit.

These figures beg the question: has there been a massive increase in the number of permanently and temporarily disabled working age Australians over the past 20 years, or has there merely been a massive increase in the proportion of working age Australians with disabilities who rely on social security benefits?

Demographer Dr Graham Hugo estimates that there has been a 16 per cent increase in the number of people with disabilities over the past decade, and that by the turn of the century one in 12 Australians will have some form of disability. While there is little doubt that the overall incidence of disability in Australian society is rising, the overwhelming reason for this increase is the larger number of old people who have chronic conditions. Medical breakthroughs now mean that elderly people who suffer from diseases which would have killed them 20 or 30 years ago are now able to continue living, although often in a severely incapacitated state of health. The combination of an ageing population and life prolonging medicines indicate that the number of very old people with disabilities will continue to rise at a faster rate than the overall population.

I have found no studies that indicate that the rate of incapacity in the working age population is rising at anywhere near the rate of increase in the number of invalid pensioners and sickness beneficiaries over the past two decades. Conversely, it is quite valid to suggest that the number of people with permanent disabilities or temporary incapacities keeping them out of the work force should have fallen during the past 20 years.

Medical breakthroughs mean that many temporary illnesses can be cured more quickly and many permanent disabilities have a less debilitating effect on a person's lifestyle. There has been a marked improvement in the knowledge, expertise and rehabilitative skills of allied health professionals such as occupational therapists, physiotherapists, speech therapists, psychologists and a range of other allied health professionals, including orthoptists, orthotists and prosthetists. I could go on at length about the level of skills of those people who have contributed to enabling people with disabilities to have a better quality of life than they would have earlier.

Equal employment opportunity and affirmative action laws have been enacted. The Federal Government's commitment to policies that promote mainstream community involvement by people with disabilities is embodied in the Disability Services Act. A wider and more diverse choice of employment and education opportunities has opened up new careers for people with disabilities. There have been marked improvements in the networks of community support available to people with disabilities. Workplaces are more accessible and material aid supports have become more technologically advanced. The development of comprehensive and generous State run workers compensation schemes-and I could spend half an hour discussing Workcare in Victoria, though not very positively-and privately funded injury and accident insurance schemes also should have reduced the reliance on social security based disability welfare.

Despite these innovations, the number of invalid pensioners has increased at four times the population rate, while the number of sickness beneficiaries has risen at 20 times the population rate since the early 1970s. Some but not all of this increase could be credited to the greater recognition and higher incidence of psychiatric, social and environmentally related diseases and impairments. However, I contend that significant advances in medicine, law, employment, education and community support which have helped alleviate the handicaps associated with disabilities far outweigh any deleterious factors over the past two decades.

So why do we have this massive increase in disability related welfare dependence over the last 20 years? One reason that cannot be overlooked is the difference in community attitudes between now and then. Twenty years ago people were far less aware of how the social security system worked. As well, there was a social stigma attached to the receipt of welfare, which was seen to represent a loss of independence and financial self-sufficiency. If one were sick, one often coped with the help of family and friends. Sadly, many of the disabled were institutionalised. However, if the disability was not considered severe the person concerned was encouraged to overcome, forget or even hide that disability and cope to the best of his or her ability. A large number of people with disabilities did just that, with the help of family and friends as well, I contend in a more compassionate and understanding society than exists today.

Neither social security take-up rates nor questionable claims that we live in a sicker, more disabled society explain this surge in disability welfare dependence. One of the basic reasons for this surge is that it has been far too easy to get onto these benefits and too easy to stay on them indefinitely. There has been little incentive offered or assistance provided to help people move off these benefits. In relation to the invalid pension, the Minister stated in his second reading speech:

We reached the stage where a person could suffer from a mild medical condition but, because of a combination of age, education, lack of skills in English, work history and worker's compensation, could end up receiving invalid pension . . . At the same time, there were a small but significant percentage of cases where relatively young people, even people in their twenties who were not manifestly impaired but were being awarded invalid pension with the expectation that they would continue to receive it on an indefinite basis.

That is not a very good record. The Minister has to admit that we have a system which is encouraging young people in their twenties to remain on this sort of support benefit for very lengthy periods, sometimes even their whole lives. In relation to the sickness benefit, the Minister stated:

The end result of these problems has been that there have been many cases where clients with impairments too insignificant to warrant grant of invalid pension have continued on sickness benefit for several years-
I interpolate here to say that in many cases it is more than several years; I have been alerted to some cases lasting for 15 or 16 years, extensive periods-
in a manner which is inappropriate to the intentions of the payment.

I would not disagree with that. In the 1989-90 financial year, the invalid pension and related benefit cost $2.8 billion compared with $0.8 billion a decade earlier. Sickness benefits cost $600m a year compared with $126m a decade earlier. By 1990-91, income support for people with disabilities and the sick had risen to more than $4 billion.

If the Government is to stem this growth in outlays it must ensure that only those people who are genuinely sick or incapacitated can access the benefits. Just as important, the Government must also ensure that all benefit recipients have a realistic opportunity to rid themselves of the shackles of welfare dependency. I emphasise that this should be all benefit recipients. I believe that that is not the case under the current legislative arrangements; there are some people who will not be encouraged as much as others. I refer to those people currently on invalid pensions.

I doubt whether this legislation will fulfil either objective. The Department shares my doubts. When asked twice by Senator Herron during the hearings of the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs about the envisaged change in the number of invalid pensioners resulting from this legislation, the departmental officer stated:
We still see it increasing but these measures would act to curb the rate of increase a little, particularly by helping people off the payment back into work.
The officer continued:
Yes, we would expect the number of claims at the margin to ease off, just as they go up when employment goes up.

These two telling remarks sum up the effect that this Bill will have on the burgeoning invalid pension and sickness benefit populations. It will result in a slight improvement at the margins. I have already referred to the enormous burgeoning of those figures. But, according to the Department, we will see a slight improvement at the margin. For example, new eligibility criteria will make it slightly harder to access the disability support pension, with 5,000 or 12 per cent fewer successful claimants annually. It will be slightly easier to access rehabilitation and training, with 4,250 and 6,500 extra places respectively by the end of 1993-94. One in three new pensioners, representing one in 25 pensioners overall, will be asked to draw up activity plans to facilitate their eventual placement in mainstream employment. Some 20 per cent of those pensioners who successfully complete activity plans will get full time work; 30 per cent will get part time work.

Entitlement for the supposedly temporary sickness allowance will be shortened to two years maximum duration. Some 8,000 or 5 per cent of sickness allowees will benefit annually from rehabilitation. Over the three years to the end of 1993-94, net savings from a program that costs the taxpayer over $4 billion a year will be $25.3m.

In judging these reforms, one must consider not only how they will impact on new recipients but also the benefits that will be derived by the 300,000-plus current invalid pensioners, their families and carers. The Government has stated that these reforms build upon the work of Bettina Cass in her Social Security Review Issues Paper No. 5 entitled Towards Enabling Policies: Income Support for People with Disabilities. On reading this paper by Cass, it is obvious that she favours the extension of these reforms to existing invalid pensioners. Two of the five objectives that she considered central to a successful income support program for people with disabilities were: first, the development of employment potential through incentives and opportunities; and, secondly, the introduction of a greater degree of flexibility to accommodate different degrees of employability. She expressed concern that the existing arrangements have actually created additional barriers to employment and entrenched labour force marginality. She concluded:

. . . a fundamental objective must be the establishment of enabling policies, those which encourage and support participation and the enhancement of capabilities rather than the entrenchment of marginality.

The Government has been very non-committal about whether existing pensioners will be given access to activity plans, panel assessment, rehabilitation and training programs. In the Government's 1990 Budget Related Paper entitled New Opportunities for People with Disabilities, the only reference to the effect of these reforms on existing pensioners was:
It will be open to such invalid pensioners to seek rehabilitation or other assistance voluntarily.
In the draft guidelines outlining the conduct of these reforms, it was stated:
. . . former invalid pensioners can volunteer to participate in an activity program but would not be subject to formal activity plans . . . as this would reduce the incentive to volunteer.

Neither of these references indicates a full-blown commitment to the enabling policies referred to by Cass. When I put this question to departmental officials during a briefing last June I was told that the emphasis would be on early intervention and hence that the concentration would be on new claimants. I was told that after 12 months it would be decided whether to extend the program to existing invalid pensioners. I was given the distinct impression that the voluntary option would not be promoted within the current pensioner population. That concerns me.

The hesitancy of the Department of Social Security in extending these reforms to current invalid pensioners was clear during the hearings of the Committee on Community Affairs when Senator Knowles requested an estimate of the number of current pensioners who would volunteer for assistance and the burden that they would place on training programs. Despite the fact that it had been claimed that pensioners could volunteer for assistance, the Department had not even estimated the number of pensioners it believed would take advantage of the offer.

It seems to me that it would have been fairly simple to take a random sample of pensioners and to ask them whether, if these programs were available, they would avail themselves of the opportunity. A reasonable sample would have given us some information about, firstly, whether people would participate in these programs and, secondly, what the demand would be on the programs. We may see a rush of people. I know of one person on an invalid pension who has developed some computer skills. If those skills were honed and refined, that person most probably would be able to make his computer operation viable in a business sense. But he needs some training. He said to me, `If I could get the opportunity to get off the invalid pension I would'. I am sure that story could be repeated around the country.

I condemn the Department for not doing such a survey, for not seeking to find out how many invalid pensioners believe they might benefit from these programs and for not giving such pensioners the opportunity to be included in a much more active way than that of merely volunteering. They should be actively encouraged to participate rather than being left somehow to find out that the program may be available to them.

It was claimed by the Department that the emphasis should be on early intervention because, generally, the experience is that the longer people stay on income support the greater their chance of staying there forever. It was claimed that the majority of current invalid pensioners were over 50 years of age and that the focus should be on new entrants, particularly young people. As I have said, I have concerns about this. I am also disappointed that such spurious grounds are being used to justify effectively scrap-heaping so many invalid pensioners. Given the time, I think that this is an appropriate place for me to stop. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —We all know that immigration can be a traumatic event in a person's life, particularly when for some reason or another an applicant finds that his or her application for migration has been refused on grounds that may be regarded as unjust or inappropriate. We also know of other cases where blatant action by a newly arrived migrant has abused the very system used to gain entry as a permanent resident.

SPEECH.PARA: I well recall the case of an Australian citizen who married a woman from the Philippines. After arrival, she immediately deserted the husband and chose to live apart. The incensed husband sought to have the woman's visa cancelled, only to be told by the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs that it had no power to do so. It should be the concern of every honourable senator when inconsistencies within the regulations and the attitude of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs in the execution of its duties are apparent.

My attention has been drawn to a particular case where the irresponsible actions of an Australian citizen, combined with the harsh application of government regulations, have, without compassion or feeling, literally dumped an English migration applicant. I am advised that the Department's compliance section has resorted to heavy-handed tactics to scare and threaten a person who has been described by the Immigration Review Tribunal in the following terms:
Her genuineness cannot be impugned . . . We are prepared to accept implicitly her genuineness.

I will briefly describe this case. An English lady came to visit her sister living in South Australia. During the visit, the visitor met and fell in love with a separated Australian citizen. Following a courtship, a relationship developed and at the end of the stay the lady returned to England.

The Australian sought and was granted a divorce from his wife. He continued to court the English lady and persuaded her to return to Australia and to consider marriage. The English lady, wanting to be sure of her feelings and the genuineness of the Australian, returned on a visitors visa on 28 September 1989 for a stay of up to six months.

In December 1989, the couple talked of marriage and inquired of the Department as to her status and whether they could marry in Australia. They were told of various changes to the regulations that were introduced that month. The following month, the couple asked the Department for advice. They explained that they had originally decided to get married in South Australia and then fly to England for a honeymoon and, whilst there, apply for a permanent residence visa under the spouse category so that they could fly back together and start their life as Australian residents together.

The problem was, however, that the man's employer could not let him remain away for too long, and thus they wanted to know how long a visa would take to be issued in England and whether it could be done quickly. The departmental officer pointed out that in the new regulations it was indeed possible to seek a change of status in Australia and apply for a temporary residence permit and then graduate to a permanent entry permit after entry. They were advised that they should go ahead with the marriage and then apply in Adelaide instead of London because it would be both safer and faster. This they did but, as it turned out, it was neither faster nor safer. An application was subsequently lodged. Incidentally, the form used-No. 690-recommended that applicants read carefully four particular covering booklets. When asking for these the applicant was told, `They have not been printed yet'.

Several weeks later and totally unexpectedly, the Australian deserted his new wife, leaving her alone and devastated. Before leaving the new wife, I understand, he had been subject to some external manipulative pressure. Several weeks later, being honest and reputable, the lady notified the Department of her changed circumstances as was required of her by regulation. The Department requested written advice with which she complied, but she received neither acknowledgment nor instruction as to her status. After subsequently being subjected to an impersonal interview at the counter of the Department in Adelaide, she was later advised in writing that her residency application had been rejected and that she had 28 days in which to depart Australia or take the opportunity to appeal against the decision through the Migration Internal Review Office. We should remember that she was still married to an Australian citizen who had walked out on her.

She instituted an appeal through the Migration Internal Review Office on 20 August 1990, attaching the reasons as to why she was appealing. The Migration Internal Review Office eventually rejected this appeal and reaffirmed the original refusal. It also gave notice of her right to appeal through the Independent Migration Review Tribunal, provided this was done within the remaining days of grace left of the original 28 days given for her departure under the original decision. She lodged the appeal on 14 January 1991. At that time she also sought legal aid, bearing in mind that she was legally married to an Australian who had left her in the lurch with no money. She also sought social security assistance for a special benefit.

The Tribunal heard the case on 1 March 1991 and subsequently handed down its determination on 5 August. This was all procedurally correct. The case put forward by the applicant to the Tribunal was logical and straightforward. It contained various arguments on the legality of the interpretation of several sections of the regulations. The Tribunal accepted these arguments and upheld the lady's point of view on these important issues, but it stopped short of approval. The question of the applicant's eligibility had been finally reduced to only one point of contention, namely, whether the marriage was really genuine in that it was intended to be a lasting union. It is a question that may well be asked of all marriages. In the view of the marriage celebrant, the bride, the bridegroom, the guests at the wedding and, indeed, many friends in the country town of Moonta in South Australia it was. But in the view of the Tribunal it was not. I remind the Senate that this was an opinion given some 18 months after the marriage and after the Tribunal talked to the husband in Darwin.

For this interview with the husband, during the questioning one Tribunal member was present in person, the other listening on a conference phone hook-up from Canberra. I quote from the report of the Tribunal at page 15:

Whilst therefore the Tribunal is prepared to accept that the husband felt love and desire for the applicant and indeed was probably very happy in the relationship as it progressed towards marriage and immediately thereafter, it is not prepared to accept that his commitment to the marriage with the applicant was such as to exclude the possibility of him sharing a life with his former wife at some stage in the future.

Although, therefore, the parties in this instance may be said to have had a mutual commitment to the marriage, unfortunately for the applicant, this commitment was not one that her husband shared with her `to the exclusion of others'.

Suddenly our Tribunal members have become expert psychologists, knowing what was in another person's mind at an event 18 months earlier. In the penultimate paragraph of the Tribunal's summary, it also states that it has every sympathy with the applicant and that the irresponsible behaviour of an Australian citizen has placed her in a position where she must face leaving the country. It also stated that it unfortunately cannot grant applications merely on the basis of strong compassionate circumstances. It concludes by saying that the law must be applied and applied correctly.

The Tribunal said that unfortunately the application failed to satisfy the criteria in subregulation 135(B) inasmuch as the Tribunal could not accept that the relationship between the applicant and her husband was a genuine one at the relevant time for the above reasons. She was therefore refused entry under the spouse class.

The lady remains legally married but has now been told by the Tribunal that, on her wedding day and after, her husband had a notion, hidden away in his mind somewhere, that one day somewhere in the future he was going to live with his first wife. Such an interpretation must raise in the minds of all reasonable senators questions about the Migration Act and the supporting regulations for which we as legislators have the final responsibility.

Was it, and indeed should it ever be, the intention of this chamber to place within such legislation, or even accept, that applicants under a spouse category should be subject to a psychological examination at the time of a marriage to determine whether or not each party has, or harbours, any hidden notion or idea that at some stage in the future-whenever that might be-they may go off and live with a former friend or spouse? I believe we would all say, `Don't be stupid, how could anyone legislate on such a boundless matter?'.

Yet here we have a decision which seeks to interpret the law and the regulations in just such a way. How on earth can anyone postulate or presume to know what another person has in his or her mind at any given time, other than guessing-particularly after a period of 18 months has elapsed? How can anyone postulate or even guess whether one person is going to remain faithful to another and for what period of time? There are flaws in the interpretative section of the Act and the regulations which do not enunciate clearly the intent of the Act and the words it uses. For this reason people are suffering injustices and being denied natural justice.

The lady approached two Labor senators from South Australia and also wrote directly to the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hand). The Minister's office actually responded in 48 hours. This is interesting in itself because on occasions I have waited six months for a response to a migration query. But her appeals were to no avail. It seems that compassion and justice are not on the agenda of this Government and its representatives, despite Labor's claims to a monopoly on compassion.

After receiving the Tribunal decision, the lady contacted the Department's compliance branch to advise it that she was thinking of lodging an appeal in the Federal Court of Australia, particularly in light of the interpretation of the Tribunal members as to what constituted her relationship. I am troubled to be advised that, in response, the Department's compliance section used suggestive comments more appropriate to police states or dictatorships, such as:
We will starve you out . . .
I know the Federal Court system, you won't win. So why don't you save us all of the expense and go quietly under our planned departure strategy . . .
When we deport you, you will become a prisoner in your own country . . .
You are classified as an illegal entrant. You are not entitled to any compassion or help from social services, so you will have to pay all the benefits back, unless you leave quietly . . .
If you go quietly under your own means, you will not suffer a long penalty of being unable to re-apply for another visa, whereas if we deport you, you must wait five years . . .
I will ensure that any payments are stopped tomorrow.

It should be noted that when the applicant lodged her forms the Department took possession of her passport with the visitor's visa stamped in it. It has never been returned. As no-one from the Department had written to her to explain that it had actually cancelled her temporary resident visa in August 1990, how could anyone expect the applicant to know her status? It was not until 19 August 1991 that she was informed by the compliance section that she had been an illegal migrant for 12 months. After all, had she not used the correct administrative process to appeal, as she had been invited to? Had she not acted in a proper and correct manner?

If we allow, through the legal process, an applicant access to an appeal mechanism, then should we not also ensure that during the period of time of the appeal special status is given to the applicant? Do we really intend that an innocent person be pilloried because of a seemingly wayward interpretation of the intent of the Act? Surely the provisions being applied in this case were included to ensure that people whose intentions were not honourable were flushed out by the requirement to establish the existence of a `genuine and lasting relationship'.

In this case, the applicant was urged to come to Australia, was wooed, courted and married by an Australian citizen and she committed herself to the marriage. She has been adjudged by the Tribunal as being genuine and honest. Yet she is now subjected to treatment as though she were an undesirable-an unwanted person. The town of Moonta feels so strongly about this person that the people are running functions to establish a fighting fund for her. She has developed an affinity with that community.

At the start of my remarks I mentioned, by comparison, the case of a Filipino lady who thwarted the Act and an Australian citizen and yet is allowed to remain in Australia legally. Here we have an applicant who has been thwarted by an Australian citizen and adverse departmental rulings and who now faces deportation. Surely none of us in this chamber would deliberately intend such an interpretation of the Act. I therefore call on the Minister and the Government to amend the regulations and to incorporate adequate interpretative meanings to the phrase `genuine and lasting relationship'.

May I add that I have been approached by three other parties, all of whom are being questioned on applications under this spouse area where the precise argument is in proving what constitutes a `genuine and lasting relationship'. They have also been asked to prove that they do cohabit with their partners. Despite the fact that one lady is pregnant and one has just had a child and has already had three others by the resident Australian-as is testified upon each child's birth certificate-each applicant has been told that such an event is hardly proof of genuine cohabitation or even of a genuine relationship! But if they can show a joint gas bill or a joint bank account then, they are told, the Department would be satisfied. What proof does the Department want, or is it hopeful of using the appeal mechanism as a fund-raiser?

Action on the interpretive clauses is a matter of urgency. In the meantime, the Department should be instructed to delay any further action on these cases until the Parliament accepts the subordinate legislation of the regulations supporting the Migration Act. It makes me extremely angry that regulations designed to prevent rorts and abuses of the system-but which so often fail to do this-are now being used to intimidate and exclude a genuine case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on a different matter altogether from the case presented by Senator Chapman. I hope that what he has said is not exactly the case, but if it is I do not think there will be many people in this place who do not sympathise with what the honourable senator has said-except that bit about compassion.

SPEECH.PARA: I was involved in an event which I found so interesting and pleasing that I want to share it with the Senate-particularly in light of the consequences. On, I think, Tuesday 20 August-I am not quite sure whether that is the right date-in the middle of the Russian coup, I tried to ring Moscow. To my amazement, I was able to get through at the height of the coup and I was able to speak to a member of the Soviet Women's Committee, Vera Soboleva, head of the international department. From speaking to the Soviet women, I noted some curious, interesting, very moving and different interpretations of what life is like in a city experiencing a coup of that sort.

One of the women said to me, `It is very unpleasant to come to work and find a tank outside the window'. That probably rates as one of the understatements of the century-particularly when one knows that those tanks have a history of use. These are not monuments standing for effect; they are not there to remind people of war; these tanks have been used. It was one way that this woman was able to convey to me the great fear that the women in the Soviet Union were experiencing.

Another woman said, `It is not very quiet'. The way they use their capacity with English-which I might say is fantastic and is certainly greatly superior to my capacity with Russian-has its own impact. That woman said, `It is not very quiet in the city. There are military and troops everywhere. We are waiting for a decision'. That sense of a city in waiting came through to us. Another woman said, `We are very concerned. We do not want civil war. We want normal conditions under which we can live'.

Then, as I suppose is often the case, with wry Soviet humour another woman said, `This morning I came to work on the public transport system. People were reading their papers or their books. The trains were running. The TV is working, the radio is working, the shops are opening and we can queue for the same absence of food'. It is that last statement in particular which reminds us that, yes, everything is the same; it is very tough indeed living in Moscow.

The women went on to say that it was the school holidays. In all of the newspaper articles that I read about the coup in the Soviet Union I do not think anyone reminded me that it was the school holidays or explored the concept of how to baby-sit or care for children in a city experiencing a coup d'etat.

That is something that many of us have not had the opportunity to think about; it would have been very frightening. Would we, for example, want to leave our children in a child-care centre on one side of a city and cross the city-passing the tanks, the people gathering and so on-to go to our workplace? I imagine that very many people in Moscow decided not to go to work or not to be separated from family. I have no idea of the numbers. It is an interesting point that came home to me from the use of the words by the Soviet women: `It is the school holidays'.

Further, the Soviet women said, `Like last year, the universities will not be returning until October because the university students will be required to assist with the harvest'. When I was in the Soviet Union with some of my colleagues from the Senate and the House of Representatives in October 1990 we learnt that the students, as well as the military, had been deployed to assist with the harvest. We learnt, and we are again reminded, of the huge wastage of food in the Soviet Union. The food is lost, wasted and destroyed in transport and destroyed because it cannot be harvested or picked off the ground in time; it just rots.

The Soviet Union has huge problems confronting it. Not only are there problems with the food-although we understand that much more food is produced than is actually delivered to the cities-but also there are transport infrastructure problems and so on. According to the women, the tough conditions of life in the Soviet Union, particularly in downtown Moscow, are not too different from when we were there-perhaps marginally worse. It is a very tough time. The words the women used when I was speaking to them gave me a dimension of the coup that, I think, we have not been reading about in the papers; a side to the coup that is really very perturbing and very moving. I was delighted to speak to the Soviet women and say that we in Australia were very concerned.
I am also delighted to say that I have received a cable from the embassy of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, forwarding a message from the Soviet Women's Committee. The cable states:
Dear Senator,

The Soviet Women's Committee extends its gratitude to you and other women members of the Australian Parliament for the support at the very difficult times. In its statement the SWC has demanded that an urgent extraordinary meeting of the Congress of Peoples Deputies of the USSR be called and that the constitutional order in the country be restored. The Committee has also stressed upon that it stands for further development of the reforms in our country, against any suppression, for observation of all civil rights and freedoms.
With deep respect,
The Soviet Women's Committee
August 24 1991

The cable was sent to me by Mr V. Kuznetsov, Charge d'Affaires at the USSR embassy. It is interesting to report to the Senate the impact that the phone call had on me. The women were very frightened, very concerned, guarded in what they had to say, and very anxious that the threat of civil war could be lifted. In particular, they were very moved that Australia should know about them and worry about them.

From talking to them, I was reminded of the impression that we got when we were in the Soviet Union: one knows more about the Soviet Union if one lives outside of it than if one lives in it. They were amazed that somehow we knew about the situation, that somehow the world might be concerned. They were moved by that and they were moved that we should be bothered to contact them and tell them that. They seemed to have less detail of what was happening in their own city than I had from watching Australian television. That was certainly the impression we had when we were in the Soviet Union. We now know the story of how the incident at Chernobyl was suppressed and not advised to the Soviet citizens. It is not restricted to Chernobyl. Other matters seem to take a long time to pass through the media networks to the Soviet citizens.

The impression that I had was of their isolation, their terrible anxiety and their huge fear. As one of the women said, `As wives and mothers, we certainly do not want any war and we do not want a civil war'. I am pleased to say that I have received this cable addressed to the women of the Australian Parliament thanking us for thinking of them at that time. I am moved and delighted that they now know that we do think of them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly to touch on a matter on which I spoke following Question Time today. I refer to the matter of Mr Colbung, the Chairman of the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies, being thrown out of the office of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister in Aboriginal Reconciliation (Mr Tickner).

SPEECH.PARA: I was appalled at the response at Question Time to my question about whether or not Mr Colbung had been thrown out, which was simply `No'. Clearly, Senator Collins was doing no more than reflecting precisely the response he had received from the Minister's office. The fact that there appeared to be no contrition, no apology or explanation in itself is, in many ways, an indictment.

What horrified me more than anything else was the response of the Government senators when I rose to speak for a few moments to present the facts as they had been given to me moments after the incident took place by Mr Colbung and his wife. My comments created much laughter and much mirth for a number of Government senators, Senator Schacht being one such senator. Senator Walsh was highly amused by it all. He was interjecting to the attraction of the Deputy Whip, Senator Faulkner. They thought it was all terribly funny. In fact, when a point of order was taken against Senator Faulkner he claimed proudly that he need not withdraw anything because all he had done was laugh during my speech.

This comes from a government which purports to have care and compassion for the Aboriginal community. In fact, the Government would have the Aboriginal community and the wider community believe that it has a mortgage on sensitivity, consideration and compassion for the Aboriginal community. It is a government that believes that only it has an empathy, an interest or an understanding. In the process, it is wringing out every last vote that can be had from the Aboriginal community and those who genuinely do have a care, an interest, an empathy and a belief in the Aboriginal community. In the broad sweep of the Government's politics, it picks up not only the Aboriginal race in the ballot boxes but also everybody else who seriously takes up their cause.

We have a living example in Ken Colbung-a 60-year old man whose sin apparently has been to serve his people for the better part of his life. He is a man who fought on behalf of his country in the Korean War. He has served his State of Western Australia on a number of occasions on boards, committees and in many other ways. He has served as Chairman over many years of the Institute of Aboriginal Studies, as it then was-now the Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies. If I remember correctly, he has been honoured by the Queen.

When Mr Ken Colbung and his wife went to see the Minister-it seems that their only sin was to go to the Minister to plead for better access to and better communication with the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs-Mr Colbung was thrown out of the Minister's office. If that was not humiliating enough, when he then turned to somebody else in the Parliament whom he knew, someone with whom he had previously had dealings, it was a source of much mirth, guffaws, laughter, interjections, jokes and snide remarks by the Government.

It is bad enough that Mr Colbung is humiliated by the Minister and the Minister's staff but the final act was the conduct of the Government members in this place. I say to the credit of the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, Senator Collins, who was responding on behalf of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, that there was a look of thunder on his face for two reasons: firstly, I suspect he really cares; and, secondly, he would be horrified at the politicking of his back bench and one or two others sitting on the front bench at the time. Perhaps it says something about the wilderness in which this Government has now lost itself; it cannot even have the sensitivity to recognise the stupidity of its own conduct, putting aside any genuine belief and any genuine care.

Now is not the moment to go into the matters which caused Mr Colbung to go to the Minister's office in the first place. When I responded to the Minister immediately following Question Time, I did not want then to have to give the history of what went on in Mr Tickner's office and what was going on in the background when he was in my office, when my office was getting phone calls asking, `Is this man giving you trouble? If he is, let us know and we will help you remove him' or words to that effect. Then two of Mr Tickner's staff were at my door on the alleged spurious ground that he had a pass that required him to be accompanied in the building. They certainly did not accompany him to my office but, upon sober and cooled reflection, they realised the difficulties they had got themselves into. It was what you might call, I suspect, a rescue operation.

I had not told Mr Colbung that this was all going on in my outer office; Mr Colbung was unaware of it. While he was very cool and objective, he was clearly angry and upset at the treatment he got. I was not about to inflame his passion or to cause him or, in fact, the Minister any more embarrassment. Today, I asked a simple question expecting a sensitive and reasonable answer. I could not extract that even from the Government. If the Government's best response is this facade of reconciliation, this public claim to care about ensuring that there is a better understanding and living relationship between the two races, if it genuinely believed in it rather than in putting up this facade of legislation, it would conduct itself privately behind the scenes and publicly in this Parliament in a different way.

As I said when I asked the question yesterday, if this is living proof, a technicolour demonstration of reconciliation, an understanding between two races, an acknowledgment of a need to be sensitive to each other's lifestyles, attitudes, beliefs and feelings-if there were a genuine belief in that-it was not demonstrated this morning after Question Time and it was not demonstrated the night before last in Mr Tickner's office.

I conclude by saying that it is nothing short of an indictment of this Government and, more particularly, it is a sober revelation of the genuine commitment of this Government and individuals in it towards the Aboriginal community. If I were a cynic, I would say that the Government sees it as a good political issue to be exploited and a whole bunch of votes to be got-nothing more and nothing less.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 16 August 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the outbreak in south-east Queensland of the exotic plant disease `pawpaw ringspot', one of the most devastating diseases of pawpaw known, and never previously detected in Australia and which can affect pumpkins, melons, zucchinis and cucumbers and the origin of which is unknown:
(1) What precautions, if any, is the Government taking to prevent such diseases from entering this country.
(2) How does the Commonwealth Government assess the biological risks associated with the importation of fruit, including pawpaw into Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister for Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) has been charged with the responsibility to ensure that adequate quarantine measures are in place to prevent introduction into Australia of serious exotic diseases, including pawpaw ringspot. Plant species known to harbour such diseases have been targeted and vegetative propagable materials are permitted entry into Australia only after they have been screened for disease in a quarantine glasshouse and found free of diseases of quarantine concern. Restrictions on importation of fruit and seeds are applied, if, they have a potential to provide an avenue for introduction of unwanted pests and diseases.
(2) Assessment of biological risks with various fruit imports, including pawpaw, is complex and requires consideration of scientific and technical aspects pertinent to a particular fruit.

In short, diseases of quarantine concern are identified and management options to minimise the risk of their introduction into Australia are investigated. Quarantine measures are determined accordingly. These may range from unrestricted entry to total prohibition or importation subject to a satisfactory treatment or sourcing from an area free from specified pests and diseases.
Fruits and seeds are not known to spread pawpaw ringspot. Therefore, AQIS has not exercised any measures, for fruit and seed imports, against pawpaw ringspot virus.
